title: I'm a teenager that just got into philosophy. What are some books by philosophers I should read? - Quora

response.answer_text: These are all brilliant, introductory books that I found incredible useful.  50 Philosophy Ideas You Really Need To Know Ben Dupre A succinct introduction to 50 important philosophy ideas. Just a brief overview that really gives you a clear idea of what to expect.  These are the 50 topics it covers. Each topic lasts 4 pages so you can get through a topic in 2/3 minutes.  Sophie’s World Jostein Gaarder Anyone who is anyone will tell you this book is genius. This is about the history of philosophy. It covers 3000 years of philosophy in a couple hundred pages. Pure brilliance and very easy to understand and get to grips with.  What does it all mean? Thomas Nagel A very short and accessible introduction to philosophy. Nine major philosophical problems covered in 101 pages. This book is all about bringing the biggest questions in philosophy to the forefront and getting you to think about them.

I gather from the phrasing “books by philosophers” that you don’t want secondary sources — people who are good at expounding the work of others You want the straight shots of whiskey, the works of original philosophers that popularizers are always expounding! Here are some, by title, author, and date. THOUGHTS by Pascal (1670), THREE DIALOGUES by George Berkeley (1713), HEROES AND HERO WORSHIP, Carlyle (1841), THE PRINCIPLES OF PSYCHOLOGY, James (1890), MATTER AND MEMORY Bergson (1896), THE PROBLEMS OF PHILOSOPHY by Bertrand Russell (1912), EXPERIENCE AND NATURE, John Dewey (1925), THE REVOLT AGAINST DUALISM, Arthur Lovejoy (1930), THE POVERTY OF HISTORICISM, Karl Popper (1957), THE HUMAN CONDITION, Hannah Arendt (1958), and Susan Haack, EVIDENCE MATTERS (2014) Ask me another day and you’d get another list.
